   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 39 y/o M w/ wet beri-beri now transferred to ICU for acute
   tachycardia/dyspnea, persistent fevers in setting of treatment for
   aspiration pneumonia.
   .
   # Tachypnea / Respiratory distress: Patient with good RSBI and NIF this
   am, however, he appears to be more weak peripherally and concern that
   if he were extubated he would tire quickly and require reintubation.
   CXR is somewhat improved this morning and bilateral pleural effusions
   appear improved.   No evidence of underlying infection currently and
   pleural fluid from thoracentesis was transudative.  [**Month (only) 51**] also be a
   central component.
   - BAL for worsening Chest CT findings
 F/U results
 if pos for
   hemosiderin-laden Macros, then check ANCA, anti-basement membrane:
   pathology still pending.  ANCA and anti-GBM ordered and results
   pending.
   - Attempt PSV/CPAP, wean sedation for NIF trial, keep TV low (400cc)
   for poss ARDS
   - Hold Tylenol
   .
   # Tachycardia: Not fluid responsive.  Likely related to fever,
   cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease.
   .
   # Altered mental status:  Multiple etiologies
 chronic EtOH ingestion,
   delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction and
   possible central pontine myelinolysis.
   - central pontine myelinolysis seen MRI brain [**2191-4-5**]. MRA is okay,
   ruling out ischemic etiology. Likely due to fast correction of
   hyponatremia on admission. Appreciate neuron recs; unfortunately, it
   an irreversible process. Can cause visual problems.
   - [**Name2 (NI) **] need for lactulose as patient is having large amounts of liquid
   diarrhea
   - Continue Keppra until outpt f/u with neuron for question of seizure
   activity on the floor
   - Simplify medication list to minimize chance of medications affecting
   mental status
   - continue nutritional support
   .
   # Fevers: Persistent fevers despite broad spectrum abx coverage (cipro,
   flagyl, vanc, zosyn -> meropenem). Now afebrile off all antibiotics,
   could represent drug fever
   **Investigation for infection source so far:
   - C. diff neg x 2
   - fluid collection in stomach, however not amenable to drainage due to
   location.
   - small fluid collection extra-axially on MRI brain; not an abscess;
   hold off on working it up further
   - pleural fluid labs
 so far NGTD
   - Continue oral hygiene; check for skin break down
   - Surveillance cultures
   - Consider repeat LP if all the above investigations negative for
   source of fever. However likely low yield, and pt is coagulopathic.
   - will check respiratory virus screen.
   - F/u ID, neuro, and neurosurg recs
   - [**Month (only) 51**] be central (CNS) in etiology, however it
s a diagnosis of
   exclusion; unlikely since MRI brain did not show any bilateral
   hypothalamic lesions, less likely
   .
   # Anemia: Pt has many reasons to be anemic; malnutrition, illness,
   guaiac pos stools. Likely having a very slow GI bleed.  Hct has been
   stable over the last several days.
   - Maintain Hct >21
   - Keep an active type and cross
   - PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Was stable in low 130s. Now improving to mid-130s
   - Highest on differential is SIADH due to pulmonary processes; will
   monitor Na for now and if worsens, do a trial of free water
   restriction.
   - TSH WNL and appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim test
   - Trend Cr
   .
   # Beri-Beri: Dry/Wet features, echo hyperdynamic.
   - Continue thiamine repletion
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR stable around 2. Likely due to alcoholic liver
   disease and malnutrition. Vit K given during this admission.
   - Will need Vit K and FFP before procedures to reverse coagulopathy
   - follow Hct.
   .
   # Etoh: Outside window for withdrawal.
   - SW consult.
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, on tube feeds.  Lasix 40 mg IV x 1
   given 2L positive yesterday.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, PPI; PT working with pt.
   .
   # Access: Left subclavian (placed [**4-4**]), A-line
   .
   # Code: full
   .

   .
   # Disposition: Pending above, consider trach/PEG if no improvement by

   This is a 39 y/o M w/ wet beri-beri now transferred to ICU for acute
   tachycardia/dyspnea, persistent fevers in setting of treatment for
   aspiration pneumonia.
   .
   # Tachypnea / Respiratory distress: Patient with good RSBI and NIF this
   am, however, he appears to be more weak peripherally and concern that
   if he were extubated he would tire quickly and require reintubation.
   CXR is somewhat improved this morning and bilateral pleural effusions
   appear improved.   No evidence of underlying infection currently and
   pleural fluid from thoracentesis was transudative.  [**Month (only) 51**] also be a
   central component.
   - BAL for worsening Chest CT findings
 F/U results
 if pos for
   hemosiderin-laden Macros, then check ANCA, anti-basement membrane:
   pathology still pending.  ANCA and anti-GBM ordered and results
   pending.
   - Attempt PSV/CPAP, wean sedation for NIF trial, keep TV low (400cc)
   for poss ARDS
   - Hold Tylenol
   .
   # Tachycardia: Not fluid responsive.  Likely related to fever,
   cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease.
   .
   # Altered mental status:  Multiple etiologies
 chronic EtOH ingestion,
   delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction and
   possible central pontine myelinolysis.
   - central pontine myelinolysis seen MRI brain [**2191-4-5**]. MRA is okay,
   ruling out ischemic etiology. Likely due to fast correction of
   hyponatremia on admission. Appreciate neuron recs; unfortunately, it
   an irreversible process. Can cause visual problems.
   - [**Name2 (NI) **] need for lactulose as patient is having large amounts of liquid
   diarrhea
   - Continue Keppra until outpt f/u with neuron for question of seizure
   activity on the floor
   - Simplify medication list to minimize chance of medications affecting
   mental status
   - continue nutritional support
   .
   # Fevers: Persistent fevers despite broad spectrum abx coverage (cipro,
   flagyl, vanc, zosyn -> meropenem). Now afebrile off all antibiotics,
   could represent drug fever
   **Investigation for infection source so far:
   - C. diff neg x 2
   - fluid collection in stomach, however not amenable to drainage due to
   location.
   - small fluid collection extra-axially on MRI brain; not an abscess;
   hold off on working it up further
   - pleural fluid labs
 so far NGTD
   - Continue oral hygiene; check for skin break down
   - Surveillance cultures
   - Consider repeat LP if all the above investigations negative for
   source of fever. However likely low yield, and pt is coagulopathic.
   - will check respiratory virus screen.
   - F/u ID, neuro, and neurosurg recs
   - [**Month (only) 51**] be central (CNS) in etiology, however it
s a diagnosis of
   exclusion; unlikely since MRI brain did not show any bilateral
   hypothalamic lesions, less likely
   .
   # Anemia: Pt has many reasons to be anemic; malnutrition, illness,
   guaiac pos stools. Likely having a very slow GI bleed.  Hct has been
   stable over the last several days.
   - Maintain Hct >21
   - Keep an active type and cross
   - PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Was stable in low 130s. Now improving to mid-130s
   - Highest on differential is SIADH due to pulmonary processes; will
   monitor Na for now and if worsens, do a trial of free water
   restriction.
   - TSH WNL and appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim test
   - Trend Cr
   .
   # Beri-Beri: Dry/Wet features, echo hyperdynamic.
   - Continue thiamine repletion
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR stable around 2. Likely due to alcoholic liver
   disease and malnutrition. Vit K given during this admission.
   - Will need Vit K and FFP before procedures to reverse coagulopathy
   - follow Hct.
   .
   # Etoh: Outside window for withdrawal.
   - SW consult.
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, on tube feeds.  Lasix 40 mg IV x 1
   given 2L positive yesterday.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, PPI; PT working with pt.
   .
   # Access: Left subclavian (placed [**4-4**]), A-line
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Communication: Patient/ Parents
   .
   # Disposition: Pending above, consider trach/PEG if no improvement by
   next week

Summary:

The patient is a 39-year-old male with wet beriberi who was transferred to the ICU for acute tachycardia and dyspnea. He has a history of aspiration pneumonia, and is currently receiving treatment for pneumonia. The patient's respiratory status has improved, but he remains intubated due to concerns about his ability to tolerate extubation. He has a central pontine myelinolysis diagnosis, which is irreversible. The patient has multiple medical issues, including tachycardia, altered mental status, and fevers, and is receiving treatment for these conditions.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Distress: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, and he is at risk for respiratory failure if not managed properly.
2. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia is not fluid responsive and is likely related to fever, cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease.
3. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status is likely due to multiple etiologies, including chronic EtOH ingestion, delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction, and possible central pontine myelinolysis.
4. Fevers: The patient's fevers are persistent despite broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage, and may represent a drug fever or an ongoing infection.
5. Anemia: The patient has multiple reasons to be anemic, including malnutrition, illness, and guaiac-positive stools, and is at risk for further bleeding.
6. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia is improving, but is still a concern, and may worsen if not managed properly.
7. Coagulopathy: The patient has a coagulopathy due to alcoholic liver disease and malnutrition, and is at risk for bleeding if not managed properly.
8. Central Pontine Myelinolysis: The patient's central pontine myelinolysis is irreversible, and he is at risk for further neurological deterioration.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust treatment as necessary.
2. Continue to manage the patient's tachycardia with medications and fluids as necessary.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's altered mental status and adjust treatment as necessary.
4. Continue to investigate the cause of the patient's fevers and adjust treatment as necessary.
5. Continue to manage the patient's anemia with transfusions and medications as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's hyponatremia and adjust treatment as necessary.
7. Continue to manage the patient's coagulopathy with medications and transfusions as necessary.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's central pontine myelinolysis and adjust treatment as necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 39-year-old male with a chief complaint of respiratory distress, admitted to the ICU for acute tachycardia and dyspnea in the setting of treatment for aspiration pneumonia. He has a history of wet beri-beri and chronic EtOH ingestion. The patient is intubated and sedated, with a recent BAL that was negative for fungal, PCP, and bacterial growth. He has a history of sepsis, pneumonia, and coagulopathy, and is currently being treated with antibiotics, anticoagulation, and nutritional support.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory distress may progress to respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation and potentially leading to ventilator-associated pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's history of sepsis and coagulopathy increases the risk of developing septic shock and multi-organ dysfunction.
3. Central Pontine Myelinolysis: The patient's recent MRI brain showed central pontine myelinolysis, which may lead to irreversible neurological damage and visual problems.
4. Hepatic Encephalopathy: The patient's history of chronic EtOH ingestion and liver dysfunction increases the risk of developing hepatic encephalopathy, which may lead to altered mental status and increased risk of bleeding.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may increase the risk of bleeding and hemorrhage, particularly in the setting of invasive procedures.
6. Malnutrition: The patient's malnutrition may exacerbate his underlying medical conditions and increase the risk of complications, particularly in the setting of sepsis.
7. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's history of hyponatremia and electrolyte imbalance may lead to neurological symptoms and increased risk of cardiac arrhythmias.
8. Infection: The patient's persistent fevers and lack of clear source of infection may indicate a high risk of developing a secondary infection, particularly in the setting of coagulopathy and malnutrition.
9. GI Bleed: The patient's guaiac-positive stools and history of malnutrition may indicate a high risk of GI bleeding, particularly in the setting of coagulopathy and anticoagulation therapy.
10. Visual Problems: The patient's central pontine myelinolysis may lead to irreversible visual problems, including blindness.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent respiratory failure.
2. Continue to treat the patient's sepsis and coagulopathy with antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy, respectively.
3. Monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent central pontine myelinolysis and hepatic encephalopathy.
4. Continue to provide nutritional support to the patient, including thiamine repletion, to prevent malnutrition and exacerbation of underlying medical conditions.
5. Monitor the patient's electrolyte balance and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent electrolyte imbalance and cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Consider repeating the patient's respiratory virus screen and fungal cultures to rule out secondary infections.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's GI status and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent GI bleeding.
8. Consider referring the patient to a neurologist and/or neurosurgeon for further evaluation and management of his central pontine myelinolysis and potential visual problems.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 39-year-old male with wet beri-beri, acute tachycardia, and dyspnea, transferred to the ICU for treatment of aspiration pneumonia. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated due to respiratory distress. The patient has a moderate bilateral pleural effusion, which is likely the main cause of his tachypnea. He is also experiencing persistent fevers despite broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage, which may indicate a drug fever.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, likely due to malnutrition, illness, and gastrointestinal bleeding. His mental status is altered, with possible causes including delirium, central pontine myelinolysis, and liver dysfunction. He is also experiencing hyponatremia, which is improving, and coagulopathy due to alcoholic liver disease and malnutrition.

The patient's condition is complex, and potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and tachypnea may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
2. Infection: The patient's persistent fevers and positive cultures may indicate a severe infection, which could lead to sepsis and organ failure.
3. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anemia and guaiac-positive stools suggest ongoing gastrointestinal bleeding, which could worsen his anemia and lead to hemodynamic instability.
4. Central pontine myelinolysis: The patient's altered mental status and MRI findings suggest central pontine myelinolysis, which is an irreversible condition that can cause visual problems and cognitive impairment.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may increase his risk of bleeding complications, particularly during procedures.
6. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's hyponatremia and potential electrolyte imbalances may lead to cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.
7. Liver dysfunction: The patient's liver dysfunction may worsen, leading to increased risk of bleeding, coagulopathy, and other complications.

Given the patient's complex condition, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent or promptly manage potential complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 39-year-old male with wet beri-beri, transferred to the ICU for acute tachycardia and dyspnea, and persistent fevers in the setting of treatment for aspiration pneumonia.
* The patient has a moderate bilateral pleural effusion, which is likely the main reason for tachypnea.
* The patient is intubated for respiratory distress, and has worsening ABG values due to fatigue.
* The patient has persistent fevers despite broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage, which may represent drug fever.
* The patient has anemia, likely due to malnutrition, illness, and gastrointestinal bleeding.
* The patient has altered mental status, likely due to delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction, and central pontine myelinolysis.
* The patient has hyponatremia, which is improving, and may be due to SIADH.
* The patient has coagulopathy, likely due to alcoholic liver disease and malnutrition.
* The patient has beri-beri, which is being managed with thiamine repletion.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Respiratory failure due to worsening pleural effusion and respiratory distress
* Sepsis due to persistent fevers and possible infection
* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to anemia and possible coagulopathy
* Central nervous system complications due to altered mental status and central pontine myelinolysis
* Electrolyte imbalances due to hyponatremia and possible coagulopathy
* Bleeding complications due to coagulopathy and possible gastrointestinal bleeding
* Infection-related complications due to possible sepsis and infection
* Nutritional deficiencies due to anemia and possible gastrointestinal bleeding

**Plan:**

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider weaning sedation for NIF trial
* Investigate the source of persistent fevers and consider repeat LP if all other investigations are negative
* Manage anemia with blood transfusions and consider gastrointestinal bleeding workup
* Continue to monitor and manage altered mental status, hyponatremia, and coagulopathy
* Consider tracheostomy and PEG tube placement if no improvement in respiratory status by next week
* Continue to monitor for signs of sepsis and infection, and consider antibiotic coverage adjustments as necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 39-year-old male with wet beri-beri, a condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the body due to thiamine deficiency. The patient was admitted to the ICU for acute tachycardia, dyspnea, and persistent fevers in the setting of treatment for aspiration pneumonia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Tachycardic (119 bpm), tachypneic (31 breaths per minute), and febrile (37.8C).
* Respiratory support: The patient is on CPAP/PSV with a FiO2 of 40%.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has hyperdynamic cardiovascular status with a blood pressure of 161/80 mmHg.
* Neurological: The patient is intubated and sedated, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 3.
* Laboratory results: The patient has anemia, hyponatremia, and coagulopathy.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised, and he may require invasive ventilation to maintain adequate oxygenation and carbon dioxide removal.
2. Cardiac failure: The patient's hyperdynamic cardiovascular status may indicate cardiac failure, which can lead to pulmonary edema, arrhythmias, and decreased cardiac output.
3. Infection: The patient's persistent fevers and coagulopathy make him susceptible to infection, particularly in the respiratory and central nervous systems.
4. Thiamine deficiency: The patient's wet beri-beri may worsen if his thiamine deficiency is not adequately managed, leading to further cardiac, neurological, and respiratory complications.
5. Malnutrition: The patient's malnutrition may exacerbate his anemia, hyponatremia, and coagulopathy, making him more susceptible to infection and further complications.
6. Central pontine myelinolysis: The patient's MRI brain scan shows signs of central pontine myelinolysis, which can lead to permanent neurological damage and visual problems.
7. Seizure activity: The patient's history of chronic ethanol ingestion and his current neurological status make him susceptible to seizure activity, which can be life-threatening if not managed promptly.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, the following plan is recommended:

1. Continue respiratory support with CPAP/PSV and wean sedation to assess the patient's ability to breathe spontaneously.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status closely and consider invasive hemodynamic monitoring to guide fluid management and vasopressor therapy.
3. Manage the patient's fever aggressively with antipyretics and cooling measures to reduce the risk of infection and cardiac complications.
4. Continue thiamine repletion to manage the patient's wet beri-beri and prevent further cardiac, neurological, and respiratory complications.
5. Monitor the patient's nutritional status closely and consider enteral nutrition to support his malnutrition and anemia.
6. Consider repeat MRI brain scans to monitor the patient's central pontine myelinolysis and assess the effectiveness of treatment.
7. Consult with neurology and neurosurgery services to assess the patient's risk of seizure activity and develop a plan for seizure prophylaxis and management.
8. Monitor the patient's coagulopathy closely and consider transfusion of fresh frozen plasma and platelets to support his coagulation status.
9. Consider repeat LP if all other investigations for infection are negative and the patient's fever persists.
10. F/u ID, neuro, and neurosurg recs.

   - Continue Keppra until outpt f/u with neuron for question of seizure

   - continue nutritional support

Summary:

The patient is a 39-year-old male with wet beri-beri, a condition caused by a thiamine deficiency, who was admitted to the ICU for persistent tachycardia, dyspnea, and fevers. He has a history of chronic ethanol ingestion, which may have contributed to his condition. The patient is intubated and requires respiratory support. He has a high output heart failure, which has not fully recovered despite treatment. He is also experiencing fever, tachycardia, and altered mental status, which may be related to his underlying condition or medications.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he requires ongoing respiratory support. He may be at risk for respiratory failure, particularly if his underlying condition worsens.
2. Cardiac failure: The patient's high output heart failure has not fully recovered, and he may be at risk for cardiac failure if his condition worsens.
3. Infection: The patient's fever and tachycardia may be related to an underlying infection, which needs to be identified and treated promptly.
4. Delirium: The patient's altered mental status may be related to his underlying condition, medications, or ICU delirium. He requires close monitoring and management to prevent further deterioration.
5. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's malnutrition may exacerbate his underlying condition, and he requires ongoing nutritional support to prevent further decline.
6. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may increase his risk of bleeding, particularly if he undergoes invasive procedures or experiences trauma.
7. Seizure activity: The patient's history of seizure activity and ongoing neurological symptoms may indicate ongoing seizure activity, which needs to be monitored and managed.
8. Central pontine myelinolysis: The patient's MRI brain shows signs of central pontine myelinolysis, which may be irreversible and potentially lead to visual problems.
9. Liver dysfunction: The patient's liver dysfunction may exacerbate his underlying condition and increase his risk of bleeding, infection, and other complications.
10. Kidney dysfunction: The patient's kidney function may be compromised, particularly if he experiences dehydration or has underlying kidney disease.

   This is a 39 y/o M w/ wet beri-beri now transferred to ICU for
   persistent tachycardia/dyspnea and fevers
   .
   # Tachypnea / Respiratory distress: Patient with good RSBI and NIF over
   weekend however extubation was not attempted due to pt
s profound
   muscle weakness and concern that he may tire quickly and require
   re-intubation.
   - Will have Trach/PEG today [**4-11**]
   - BAL done for worsening Chest CT findings
 F/U results
 if pos for
   hemosiderin-laden Macros, pathology still pending.  ANCA and anti-GBM
   ordered and results pending.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Not fluid responsive.  Likely related to fever,
   cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease.
   .
   # Altered mental status:  Multiple etiologies
 chronic EtOH ingestion,
   delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction,
   dry beri beri and central pontine myelinolysis.
   - central pontine myelinolysis seen MRI brain [**2191-4-5**]. MRA is okay,
   ruling out ischemic etiology. Likely due to fast correction of
   hyponatremia on admission. Appreciate Neuro recs; unfortunately, it
   an irreversible process. Can cause visual problems.
   - Minimize sedating medications. Zyprexa may work better for delirium
   component of his mental status.
   - f/u neuro recs re: prognosis for cognitive recovery, any other
   necessary tests for work up, and the use of zyprexa for discomfort and
   agitation
   - No need for lactulose as patient is having large amounts of liquid
   diarrhea
   - Continue Keppra until outpt f/u with Neuro for question of seizure
   activity earlier in admission
   - continue nutritional support
   .
   # Fevers: Persistent fevers despite broad spectrum abx coverage (cipro,
   flagyl, vanc, zosyn -> meropenem). Was afebrile off all antibiotics,
   which could represent drug fever, but now T max 100.5F [**4-11**]
   **Investigation for infection source so far:
   - Bronch
 BAL so far unrevealing. F/u on outstanding studies.
   - C. diff neg x 2
   - fluid collection in stomach seen on imaging, however not amenable to
   drainage due to location.
   - small fluid collection extra-axially on MRI brain; not an abscess;
   hold off on working it up further
   - pleural fluid labs
 so far NGTD
   - Continue oral hygiene; check for skin break down
   - Surveillance cultures
   - Consider repeat LP if all the above investigations negative for
   source of fever. However likely low yield, and pt is coagulopathic.
   - Consider paracentesis, although not much ascitic fluid seen by U/S.
   ([**Month (only) 51**] need IR for this)
   - RSV neg
   - F/u ID, neuro, and neurosurg recs
   - [**Month (only) 51**] be central (CNS) in etiology, however it
s a diagnosis of
   exclusion; considered unlikely since MRI brain did not show any
   bilateral hypothalamic lesions, however still in differential.
   .
   # Anemia: Pt has many reasons to be anemic; malnutrition, illness,
   guaiac pos stools. Likely having a very slow GI bleed.  Hct has been
   stable over the last several days.
   - Maintain Hct >21
   - Keep an active type and cross
   - PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Was stable in low 130s. Now improving to mid-130s
   - Highest on differential is SIADH due to pulmonary processes; will
   monitor Na for now and if worsens, do a trial of free water
   restriction.
   - TSH WNL and appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim test
   - Trend Cr
   .
   # Beri-Beri: Dry/Wet features, echo hyperdynamic.
   - Continue B vitamins at increased doses, incl thiamine and pyridoxine
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR stable around 2. Likely due to alcoholic liver
   disease and malnutrition. Vit K given during this admission.
   - Will need Vit K and FFP before procedures to reverse coagulopathy (2U
   FFP today [**4-11**] prior to trach/PEG)
   - follow Hct.
   .
   # Rash: developed raised, blanchable lesions trunk > extremities [**4-10**]
   - Derm input: watch for signs of mucosal involvement
   .
   # Etoh: Outside window for withdrawal.
   - SW consult.
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, on tube feeds.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, PPI; PT working with pt.
   .
   # Access: Left subclavian (placed [**4-4**]), A-line
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Communication: Patient/ Parents.
   .

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 39-year-old male with wet beri-beri who was transferred to the ICU due to persistent tachycardia, dyspnea, and fevers. The patient has a complex medical history, including chronic EtOH ingestion, delirium, and liver dysfunction.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode. The patient has a respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) test result that is negative.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a tachycardia with a heart rate of 116 beats per minute, and the blood pressure is 140/98 mmHg.
* Neurological: The patient has altered mental status, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 8. The patient is not following commands and has a poor level of consciousness.
* Hematological: The patient has anemia with a hemoglobin level of 8.5 g/dL and a hematocrit of 24.6%.
* Renal: The patient has acute kidney injury (AKI) with a creatinine level of 0.5 mg/dL.
* Infectious: The patient has a fever with a temperature of 100.5F (38.1C) and has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

The patient's medical conditions and potential complications include:

* Wet beri-beri: The patient has a diagnosis of wet beri-beri, which is a condition caused by a deficiency of thiamine.
* Tachycardia: The patient has a tachycardia with a heart rate of 116 beats per minute, which may be related to the patient's underlying medical conditions, such as cardiomyopathy and central disease.
* Altered mental status: The patient has altered mental status, which may be related to the patient's underlying medical conditions, such as delirium, liver dysfunction, and dry beri-beri.
* Anemia: The patient has anemia with a hemoglobin level of 8.5 g/dL, which may be related to the patient's underlying medical conditions, such as malnutrition and chronic EtOH ingestion.
* Coagulopathy: The patient has a coagulopathy with an international normalized ratio (INR) of 2.0, which may be related to the patient's underlying medical conditions, such as liver disease and malnutrition.
* Rash: The patient has a rash with raised, blanchable lesions on the trunk and extremities, which may be related to the patient's underlying medical conditions, such as drug rash.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) to improve nutrition and respiratory function.
* Broad-spectrum antibiotics to treat potential infections.
* Vasopressors to support blood pressure.
* Sedation to manage agitation and discomfort.
* Pain management to manage pain and discomfort.
* Nutrition support to improve nutrition and hydration.
* Rehabilitation to improve functional status.

The patient's potential complications include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient may experience respiratory failure due to the patient's underlying medical conditions, such as wet beri-beri and cardiomyopathy.
* Cardiac arrest: The patient may experience cardiac arrest due to the patient's underlying medical conditions, such as cardiomyopathy and coagulopathy.
* Sepsis: The patient may experience sepsis due to the patient's underlying medical conditions, such as pneumonia and urinary tract infection.
* Organ failure: The patient may experience organ failure due to the patient's underlying medical conditions, such as kidney failure and liver failure.
* Death: The patient may experience death due to the patient's underlying medical conditions, such as cardiomyopathy, coagulopathy, and sepsis.

   dry beri beri and central pontine myelinolysis.
   - central pontine myelinolysis seen MRI brain [**2191-4-5**]. MRA is okay,
   ruling out ischemic etiology. Likely due to fast correction of
   hyponatremia on admission. Appreciate Neuro recs; unfortunately, it
   an irreversible process. Can cause visual problems.
   - Minimize sedating medications. Zyprexa may work better for delirium
   component of his mental status.
   - f/u neuro recs re: prognosis for cognitive recovery, any other
   necessary tests for work up, and the use of zyprexa for discomfort and
   agitation
   - No need for lactulose as patient is having large amounts of liquid
   diarrhea
   - Consider d/c Keppra for possible drug rash
 f/u with Neuro
   - continue nutritional support
   .
   # Fevers: Persistent fevers despite broad spectrum abx coverage (cipro,
   flagyl, vanc, zosyn -> meropenem). Was afebrile off all antibiotics,
   which could represent drug fever, but now T max 100.5F [**4-11**]
   **Investigation for infection source so far:
   - Bronch
 BAL so far unrevealing. F/u on outstanding studies.
   - C. diff neg x 2
   - fluid collection in stomach seen on imaging, however not amenable to
   drainage due to location.
   - small fluid collection extra-axially on MRI brain; not an abscess;
   hold off on working it up further
   - pleural fluid labs
 so far NGTD
   - Continue oral hygiene; check for skin break down
   - Surveillance cultures
   - Consider repeat LP if all the above investigations negative for
   source of fever. However likely low yield, and pt is coagulopathic.
   - Consider paracentesis, although not much ascitic fluid seen by U/S.
   ([**Month (only) 51**] need IR for this)
   - RSV neg
   - F/u ID, neuro, and neurosurg recs
   - [**Month (only) 51**] be central (CNS) in etiology, however it
s a diagnosis of
   exclusion; considered unlikely since MRI brain did not show any
   bilateral hypothalamic lesions, however still in differential.
   .
   # Anemia: Pt has many reasons to be anemic; malnutrition, illness,
   guaiac pos stools. Likely having a very slow GI bleed.  Hct has been
   stable over the last several days.
   - Maintain Hct >21
   - Keep an active type and cross
   - PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Was stable in low 130s. Now improving to mid-130s
   - Highest on differential is SIADH due to pulmonary processes; will
   monitor Na for now and if worsens, do a trial of free water
   restriction.
   - TSH WNL and appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim test
   - Trend Cr
   .
   # Beri-Beri: Dry/Wet features, echo hyperdynamic.
   - Continue B vitamins at increased doses, incl thiamine and pyridoxine
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR stable around 2. Likely due to alcoholic liver
   disease and malnutrition. Vit K given during this admission.
   - Will need Vit K and FFP before procedures to reverse coagulopathy (2U
   FFP today [**4-11**] prior to trach/PEG)
   - follow Hct.
   .
   # Rash: developed raised, blanchable lesions trunk > extremities [**4-10**]
   - Derm input: watch for signs of mucosal involvement
   - Consider d/c Keppra
 f/u with Neuro
   .
   # Etoh: Outside window for withdrawal.
   - SW consult.
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, on tube feeds.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, PPI; PT working with pt.
   .
   # Access: Left subclavian (placed [**4-4**]), A-line, PICC to be placed
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Communication: Patient/ Parents.
   .
   # Disposition: Once Trach/PEG in place, ask case management to start
   screening for placement.
   - Family would like the patient to go to [**Hospital 189**] Rehab once medically

   - Need to ask SW or case management to help file long-term disability

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 39-year-old male with wet beri-beri, who was transferred to the ICU for persistent tachycardia, dyspnea, and fevers. The patient has a complex medical history, including chronic ethanol ingestion, liver dysfunction, and central pontine myelinolysis.

Current medical issues:

1. Tachypnea/Respiratory distress: The patient has persistent tachypnea and respiratory distress despite good RSBI and NIF over the weekend. Extubation was not attempted due to the patient's profound muscle weakness.
2. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia is not fluid responsive and is likely related to fever, cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease.
3. Altered mental status: The patient has multiple etiologies for altered mental status, including chronic ethanol ingestion, delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction, dry beri beri, and central pontine myelinolysis.
4. Fevers: The patient has persistent fevers despite broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage. Investigation for infection source is ongoing.
5. Anemia: The patient has multiple reasons to be anemic, including malnutrition, illness, and guaiac-positive stools. Hct has been stable over the last several days.
6. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia is improving to mid-130s. The highest differential is SIADH due to pulmonary processes.
7. Beri-Beri: The patient has dry/wet features, and echo hyperdynamic.
8. Coagulopathy: The patient has an INR stable around 2, likely due to alcoholic liver disease and malnutrition.
9. Rash: The patient developed raised, blanchable lesions on the trunk and extremities, likely an early drug rash.
10. Etoh: The patient has chronic ethanol ingestion and is outside the window for withdrawal.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and tachypnea may lead to respiratory failure if not managed promptly.
2. Sepsis: The patient's persistent fevers and altered mental status may indicate sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
3. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anemia and guaiac-positive stools may indicate a slow gastrointestinal bleed, which can worsen if not managed.
4. Central nervous system dysfunction: The patient's altered mental status and central pontine myelinolysis may lead to long-term cognitive impairment and other central nervous system dysfunction.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and cardiomyopathy may lead to cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure.

Assessment and plan:

1. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory distress and tachypnea with CPAP/PSV and monitor for signs of respiratory failure.
2. Investigate the source of the patient's fevers and continue broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage.
3. Manage the patient's anemia with blood transfusions and monitor for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding.
4. Continue to manage the patient's hyponatremia and monitor for signs of SIADH.
5. Continue to manage the patient's coagulopathy with Vitamin K and FFP and monitor for signs of bleeding.
6. Monitor the patient's rash for signs of mucosal involvement and consider discontinuing Keppra if necessary.
7. Provide nutritional support and monitor for signs of malnutrition.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolytes and adjust therapy as necessary.
9. Consider repeat LP if all other investigations are negative for the source of the patient's fever.
10. Consult with the patient's family and healthcare providers to determine the best course of treatment and disposition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is mechanically ventilated and has impaired airway clearance, ventilation, and cough. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a SpO2 of 94% and a RSBI of 98.
* Cardiovascular: The patient is hypertensive, with a systolic blood pressure in the 140s-150s. The patient's heart rhythm is sinus tachycardia, with a heart rate of 116 beats per minute.
* Neurological: The patient is intubated and has altered mental status, with eyes open but not tracking. The patient is not following commands and is moving their lips, but it is unclear if this is purposeful.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has impaired gut function, with a lack of bowel sounds and a high risk of aspiration.
* Skin: The patient has a new rash, likely an early drug rash, which is expected to evolve and expand distally over the next few days.
* Fluid status: The patient is receiving IV fluids and has a positive fluid balance, with a total input of 1,781 mL and a total output of 1,035 mL.
* Laboratory results: The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and liver enzymes, as well as impaired kidney function.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's impaired airway clearance and ventilation may lead to further respiratory compromise.
* Sepsis: The patient's altered mental status, fever, and elevated white blood cell count may indicate the development of sepsis.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's impaired gut function and high risk of aspiration may lead to gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Skin infection: The patient's new rash may become infected, leading to further complications.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension may increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias.
* Renal failure: The patient's impaired kidney function and fluid overload may lead to renal failure.
* Pneumonia: The patient's impaired airway clearance and ventilation may lead to the development of pneumonia.
* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation may increase the risk of VAP.
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's immobilization and impaired circulation may increase the risk of DVT.

Based on the patient's current condition, it is recommended that the patient continue to receive mechanical ventilation and supportive care, with close monitoring of their respiratory, cardiovascular, and neurological status. The patient's laboratory results should be closely monitored, and the patient should be assessed for signs of sepsis, gastrointestinal bleeding, and skin infection.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38.1C (100.5F), heart rate of 116 beats per minute, and blood pressure ranging from 140/98 to 173/122 mmHg. Their respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and their oxygen saturation is 94%.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 12.7, hemoglobin level of 8.5 g/dL, and platelet count of 225 K/uL. Their electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated lactate level of 0.7 mmol/L.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to their critical condition, but they are able to respond to stimuli and have impaired motor function.

The patient's assessment and plan include respiratory failure, impaired skin integrity, airway clearance, balance, muscle performance, motor function, posture, ventilation, and cough. They also have altered mental status, fever, dyspnea, tachycardia, and a problem related to their [**Last Name 12**] issue.

The patient's ICU care plan includes nutrition, glycemic control, lines, prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia. The patient's code status is unknown, and their disposition is unclear.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Given the patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation and impaired airway clearance.
2. Sepsis: With the patient's impaired immune function and elevated lactate level.
3. Wound infection: Due to the patient's impaired skin integrity and presence of a tracheostomy.
4. Pneumonia: Given the patient's impaired respiratory function and potential aspiration.
5. Cardiac complications: With the patient's hypertensive blood pressure and tachycardia.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: Due to the patient's impaired coagulation function and stress ulcer prophylaxis.
7. Renal failure: With the patient's impaired renal function and potential electrolyte imbalances.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust their treatment plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications and optimize their outcomes.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 39 y/o M w/ wet beri-beri now transferred to ICU for
   persistent tachycardia/dyspnea and fevers
   .
   # Tachypnea / Respiratory distress: Patient with good RSBI and NIF over
   weekend however extubation was not attempted due to pt
s profound
   muscle weakness and concern that he may tire quickly and require
   re-intubation.  Trach placed [**4-11**].
   - Will attempt trach mask trial
   - Still awaiting BAL results (if pos for hemosiderin-laden Macros,
   pathology still pending).  ANCA and anti-GBM ordered and results
   pending.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Not fluid responsive. Stable. Likely related to fever,
   cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease. Also starting to become
   hypertensive.
   - stop captopril due to propensity to cause rashes
   - start metoprolol 12.5 mg TID and titrate upward as necessary
   .
   # Altered mental status:  Multiple etiologies
 chronic EtOH ingestion,
   delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction,
   dry beri beri and central pontine myelinolysis.
   - potential central pontine myelinolysis seen MRI brain [**2191-4-5**]. MRA is
   okay, ruling out ischemic etiology. Likely due to fast correction of
   hyponatremia on admission. Appreciate Neuro recs; unfortunately, it
   an irreversible process. Can cause visual problems.
   - Minimize sedating medications. Zyprexa may work better for delirium
   component of his mental status.
   - f/u neuro recs re: prognosis for cognitive recovery, any other
   necessary tests for work up, and the use of zyprexa for discomfort and
   agitation
   - No need for lactulose as patient is having large amounts of liquid
   diarrhea
   - Keppra stopped as potential cause for rash
 f/u with Neuro
   - continue nutritional support
   .
   # Fevers: Persistent fevers despite broad spectrum abx coverage (cipro,
   flagyl, vanc, zosyn -> meropenem) and was less febrile off all
   antibiotics.  Fever last night could represent drug fever.  ID has
   signed off, but will let them know that he is still spiking fevers.
   **Investigation for infection source so far:
   - Bronch
 BAL so far unrevealing. F/u on outstanding studies.
   - C. diff neg multiple times
   - fluid collection in stomach seen on imaging, however not amenable to
   drainage due to location.
   - small fluid collection extra-axially on MRI brain; not an abscess;
   repeat MRI [**4-12**]
   - pleural fluid labs
 so far NGTD
   - Continue oral hygiene; check for skin break down
   - Surveillance cultures
   - Consider repeat LP if all the above investigations negative for
   source of fever. However likely low yield, and pt is coagulopathic.
   - Consider paracentesis, although not much ascitic fluid seen by U/S.
   ([**Month (only) 51**] need IR for this)
   - RSV neg
   - F/u ID, neuro, and neurosurg recs
   - [**Month (only) 51**] be central (CNS) in etiology, however it
s a diagnosis of
   exclusion; considered unlikely since MRI brain did not show any
   bilateral hypothalamic lesions, however still in differential.
   .
   # Anemia: Pt has many reasons to be anemic; malnutrition, illness,
   guaiac pos stools. Likely having a very slow GI bleed.  Hct has been
   stable over the last several days.
   - Maintain Hct >21
   - Keep an active type and cross
   - PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Resolved.  Was stable in low 130s. Now improved to mid
   140s.
   - TSH WNL and appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim test
   - Trend Cr
   .
   # Beri-Beri: Dry/Wet features, echo hyperdynamic.
   - Continue B vitamins at increased doses, incl thiamine and pyridoxine
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR stable around 2. Likely due to alcoholic liver
   disease and malnutrition. Vit K given during this admission.
   - Will need Vit K and FFP before procedures to reverse coagulopathy (2U
   FFP [**4-11**] prior to trach/PEG)
   - follow Hct.
   .
   # Rash: developed raised, blanchable lesions trunk > extremities [**4-10**]
   - Derm input: watch for signs of mucosal involvement
   - Keppra and captopril stopped
 f/u with Neuro
   .
   # Etoh: Outside window for withdrawal.
   - SW consult.
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, on tube feeds.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, PPI; PT working with pt.
   .
   # Access: Left subclavian removed (placed [**4-4**]), A-line, peripheral,
   PICC to be placed
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Communication: Patient/ Parents.
   .
   # Disposition: Once Trach/PEG in place, ask case management to start
   screening for placement.
   - Family would like the patient to go to [**Hospital 189**] Rehab once medically
   ready.
   - Need to ask SW or case management to help file long-term disability
   papers.

   This is a 39 y/o M w/ wet beri-beri now transferred to ICU for
   persistent tachycardia/dyspnea and fevers
   .
   # Tachypnea / Respiratory distress: Patient with good RSBI and NIF over
   weekend however extubation was not attempted due to pt
s profound
   muscle weakness and concern that he may tire quickly and require
   re-intubation.  Trach placed [**4-11**].
   - Will attempt trach mask trial
   - Still awaiting BAL results (if pos for hemosiderin-laden Macros,
   pathology still pending).  ANCA and anti-GBM ordered and results
   pending.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Not fluid responsive. Stable. Likely related to fever,
   cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease. Also starting to become
   hypertensive.
   - stop captopril due to propensity to cause rashes
   - start metoprolol 12.5 mg TID and titrate upward as necessary
   .
   # Altered mental status:  Multiple etiologies
 chronic EtOH ingestion,
   delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction,
   dry beri beri and central pontine myelinolysis.
   - potential central pontine myelinolysis seen MRI brain [**2191-4-5**]. MRA is
   okay, ruling out ischemic etiology. Likely due to fast correction of
   hyponatremia on admission. Appreciate Neuro recs; unfortunately, it
   an irreversible process. Can cause visual problems.
   - Minimize sedating medications. Zyprexa may work better for delirium
   component of his mental status.
   - f/u neuro recs re: prognosis for cognitive recovery, any other
   necessary tests for work up, and the use of zyprexa for discomfort and
   agitation
   - No need for lactulose as patient is having large amounts of liquid
   diarrhea
   - Keppra stopped as potential cause for rash
 f/u with Neuro
   - continue nutritional support
   .
   # Fevers: Persistent fevers despite broad spectrum abx coverage (cipro,
   flagyl, vanc, zosyn -> meropenem) and was less febrile off all
   antibiotics.  Fever last night could represent drug fever.  ID has
   signed off, but will let them know that he is still spiking fevers.
   **Investigation for infection source so far:
   - Bronch
 BAL so far unrevealing. F/u on outstanding studies.
   - C. diff neg multiple times
   - fluid collection in stomach seen on imaging, however not amenable to
   drainage due to location.
   - small fluid collection extra-axially on MRI brain; not an abscess;
   repeat MRI [**4-12**]
   - pleural fluid labs
 so far NGTD
   - Continue oral hygiene; check for skin break down
   - Surveillance cultures
   - Consider repeat LP if all the above investigations negative for
   source of fever. However likely low yield, and pt is coagulopathic.
   - Consider paracentesis, although not much ascitic fluid seen by U/S.
   ([**Month (only) 51**] need IR for this)
   - RSV neg
   - F/u ID, neuro, and neurosurg recs
   - [**Month (only) 51**] be central (CNS) in etiology, however it
s a diagnosis of
   exclusion; considered unlikely since MRI brain did not show any
   bilateral hypothalamic lesions, however still in differential.
   .
   # Anemia: Pt has many reasons to be anemic; malnutrition, illness,
   guaiac pos stools. Likely having a very slow GI bleed.  Hct has been
   stable over the last several days.
   - Maintain Hct >21
   - Keep an active type and cross
   - PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Resolved.  Was stable in low 130s. Now improved to mid
   140s.
   - TSH WNL and appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim test
   - Trend Cr
   .
   # Beri-Beri: Dry/Wet features, echo hyperdynamic.
   - Continue B vitamins at increased doses, incl thiamine and pyridoxine
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR stable around 2. Likely due to alcoholic liver
   disease and malnutrition. Vit K given during this admission.
   - Will need Vit K and FFP before procedures to reverse coagulopathy (2U
   FFP [**4-11**] prior to trach/PEG)
   - follow Hct.
   .
   # Rash: developed raised, blanchable lesions trunk > extremities [**4-10**]
   - Derm input: watch for signs of mucosal involvement
   - Keppra and captopril stopped
 f/u with Neuro
   .
   # Etoh: Outside window for withdrawal.
   - SW consult.
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, on tube feeds.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, PPI; PT working with pt.
   .
   # Access: Left subclavian removed (placed [**4-4**]), A-line, peripheral,
   PICC to be placed
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Communication: Patient/ Parents.
   .
   # Disposition: Once Trach/PEG in place, ask case management to start
   screening for placement.
   - Family would like the patient to go to [**Hospital 189**] Rehab once medically
   ready.
   - Need to ask SW or case management to help file long-term disability

Summary:

The patient is a 39-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU for persistent tachycardia, dyspnea, and fevers. He has a history of wet beri-beri and chronic ethanol ingestion. The patient's condition has been complicated by multiple medical issues, including:

* Fever: The patient has had persistent fevers despite broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage. The source of the fever is still unknown.
* Tachypnea: The patient has been experiencing tachypnea, which is likely related to his underlying medical condition and respiratory distress.
* Tachycardia: The patient's heart rate is elevated, which is likely related to his fever, cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease.
* Altered mental status: The patient has altered mental status, which is likely related to his chronic ethanol ingestion, delirium from his acute illness, and ICU setting.
* Anemia: The patient has anemia, which is likely related to his malnutrition, illness, and guaiac-positive stools.
* Hyponatremia: The patient's sodium levels are normal, but he had been experiencing hyponatremia in the past.
* Beri-Beri: The patient has dry and wet features of beri-beri, which is likely related to his malnutrition and vitamin deficiencies.
* Coagulopathy: The patient has an elevated INR, which is likely related to his alcoholic liver disease and malnutrition.
* Rash: The patient has developed a morbilliform rash, which is likely related to his medication and underlying medical condition.

Potential medical complications:

* Sepsis: The patient's persistent fevers and tachycardia make him at risk for developing sepsis.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and respiratory distress make him at risk for developing respiratory failure.
* Cardiac arrest: The patient's tachycardia and cardiomyopathy make him at risk for developing cardiac arrest.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anemia and guaiac-positive stools make him at risk for developing gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Central pontine myelinolysis: The patient's altered mental status and MRI findings suggest that he may be at risk for developing central pontine myelinolysis.
* Infection: The patient's persistent fevers and respiratory distress make him at risk for developing an infection.
* Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's malnutrition and beri-beri make him at risk for developing nutritional deficiencies.
* Coagulopathy: The patient's elevated INR and coagulopathy make him at risk for bleeding complications.

Plan:

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results.
* Continue to treat the patient's fever with antibiotics and antipyretics.
* Continue to provide respiratory support with CPAP/PSV.
* Continue to provide nutritional support with tube feeds and vitamins.
* Continue to monitor the patient's coagulation status and provide platelet transfusions as needed.
* Consider repeating the patient's MRI and MRA to rule out any other potential causes of his symptoms.
* Consider repeating the patient's BAL and pleural fluid cultures to rule out any other potential causes of his symptoms.
* Consider repeating the patient's ECG and echocardiogram to rule out any other potential causes of his symptoms.
* Continue to provide pain management with opioids and benzodiazepines.
* Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and provide sedation as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and provide antacids and anti-diarrheal agents as needed.
* Consider repeating the patient's blood cultures and urinalysis to rule out any other potential causes of his symptoms.
* Consider repeating the patient's liver function tests and kidney function tests to rule out any other potential causes of his symptoms.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 39 y/o M w/ wet beri-beri now transferred to ICU for
   persistent tachycardia/dyspnea and fevers
   .
   # Tachypnea / Respiratory distress: Patient with good RSBI and NIF over
   weekend however extubation was not attempted due to pt
s profound
   muscle weakness and concern that he may tire quickly and require
   re-intubation.
   - Will have Trach/PEG today [**4-11**]
   - BAL done for worsening Chest CT findings
 F/U results
 if pos for
   hemosiderin-laden Macros, pathology still pending.  ANCA and anti-GBM
   ordered and results pending.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Not fluid responsive. Stable. Likely related to fever,
   cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease. Also starting to become
   hypertensive. Will not increase captopril at this time due to overall
   status.
   .
   # Altered mental status:  Multiple etiologies
 chronic EtOH ingestion,
   delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction,
   dry beri beri and central pontine myelinolysis.
   - central pontine myelinolysis seen MRI brain [**2191-4-5**]. MRA is okay,
   ruling out ischemic etiology. Likely due to fast correction of
   hyponatremia on admission. Appreciate Neuro recs; unfortunately, it
   an irreversible process. Can cause visual problems.
   - Minimize sedating medications. Zyprexa may work better for delirium
   component of his mental status.
   - f/u neuro recs re: prognosis for cognitive recovery, any other
   necessary tests for work up, and the use of zyprexa for discomfort and
   agitation
   - No need for lactulose as patient is having large amounts of liquid
   diarrhea
   - Consider d/c Keppra for possible drug rash
 f/u with Neuro
   - continue nutritional support
   .
   # Fevers: Persistent fevers despite broad spectrum abx coverage (cipro,
   flagyl, vanc, zosyn -> meropenem). Was afebrile off all antibiotics,
   which could represent drug fever, but now T max 100.5F [**4-11**]
   **Investigation for infection source so far:
   - Bronch
 BAL so far unrevealing. F/u on outstanding studies.
   - C. diff neg x 2
   - fluid collection in stomach seen on imaging, however not amenable to
   drainage due to location.
   - small fluid collection extra-axially on MRI brain; not an abscess;
   hold off on working it up further
   - pleural fluid labs
 so far NGTD
   - Continue oral hygiene; check for skin break down
   - Surveillance cultures
   - Consider repeat LP if all the above investigations negative for
   source of fever. However likely low yield, and pt is coagulopathic.
   - Consider paracentesis, although not much ascitic fluid seen by U/S.
   ([**Month (only) 51**] need IR for this)
   - RSV neg
   - F/u ID, neuro, and neurosurg recs
   - [**Month (only) 51**] be central (CNS) in etiology, however it
s a diagnosis of
   exclusion; considered unlikely since MRI brain did not show any
   bilateral hypothalamic lesions, however still in differential.
   .
   # Anemia: Pt has many reasons to be anemic; malnutrition, illness,
   guaiac pos stools. Likely having a very slow GI bleed.  Hct has been
   stable over the last several days.
   - Maintain Hct >21
   - Keep an active type and cross
   - PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Was stable in low 130s. Now improving to mid-130s
   - Highest on differential is SIADH due to pulmonary processes; will
   monitor Na for now and if worsens, do a trial of free water
   restriction.
   - TSH WNL and appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim test
   - Trend Cr
   .
   # Beri-Beri: Dry/Wet features, echo hyperdynamic.
   - Continue B vitamins at increased doses, incl thiamine and pyridoxine
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR stable around 2. Likely due to alcoholic liver
   disease and malnutrition. Vit K given during this admission.
   - Will need Vit K and FFP before procedures to reverse coagulopathy (2U
   FFP today [**4-11**] prior to trach/PEG)
   - follow Hct.
   .
   # Rash: developed raised, blanchable lesions trunk > extremities [**4-10**]
   - Derm input: watch for signs of mucosal involvement
   - Consider d/c Keppra
 f/u with Neuro
   .
   # Etoh: Outside window for withdrawal.
   - SW consult.
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, on tube feeds.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, PPI; PT working with pt.
   .
   # Access: Left subclavian (placed [**4-4**]), A-line, PICC to be placed
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Communication: Patient/ Parents.
   .
   # Disposition: Once Trach/PEG in place, ask case management to start
   screening for placement.
   - Family would like the patient to go to [**Hospital 189**] Rehab once medically
   ready.
   - Need to ask SW or case management to help file long-term disability
   papers.
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 39-year-old male with wet beri-beri, transferred to the ICU for persistent tachycardia, dyspnea, and fevers. He has a history of chronic EtOH ingestion, delirium, and central pontine myelinolysis. The patient has undergone multiple procedures, including tracheostomy, and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation. He has a fever of 101.7F, and his blood cultures are pending. The patient has a coagulopathy, anemia, and hyponatremia, and is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's persistent fever and tachycardia suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory distress and requirement for mechanical ventilation increase the risk of respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac Complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension may indicate cardiac complications, such as cardiomyopathy or arrhythmias.
4. Neurological Complications: The patient's altered mental status, which is attributed to delirium, central pontine myelinolysis, and liver dysfunction, may worsen or lead to further neurological complications, such as seizures or coma.
5. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's guaiac-positive stools and anemia suggest the possibility of gastrointestinal bleeding, which could lead to hemorrhagic shock.
6. Infection: The patient's persistent fever and negative blood cultures suggest the possibility of an ongoing infection, which could lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
7. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy increases the risk of bleeding complications, such as intracranial hemorrhage or gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's hyponatremia and hyperkalemia increase the risk of electrolyte imbalance, which could lead to cardiac arrhythmias or muscle weakness.
9. Malnutrition: The patient's malnutrition and anemia increase the risk of further complications, such as weakness, fatigue, and impaired wound healing.
10. Central Nervous System Complications: The patient's central pontine myelinolysis and possible SIADH increase the risk of central nervous system complications, such as seizures, coma, or death.

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a history of respiratory failure, impaired skin integrity, tachycardia, dyspnea, fever, and altered mental status. The patient has been on tracheostomy tube and ventilator support, and has undergone an MRI head. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37C, heart rate of 112 bpm, and blood pressure of 155/82 mmHg. The patient has a morbilliform rash and is showing signs of impaired respiratory, cardiovascular, and neurological function.

Potential medical complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's fever and respiratory failure may be indicative of a pulmonary infection, such as pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever, tachycardia, and altered mental status may be signs of sepsis, a life-threatening condition that requires prompt recognition and treatment.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's impaired respiratory function may lead to respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening if not managed promptly.
4. Skin infection: The patient's morbilliform rash may be a sign of a skin infection, which can spread and cause serious complications if left untreated.
5. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension may indicate cardiovascular instability, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, or even cardiac arrest.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status may be a sign of neurological complications, such as cerebral edema, seizures, or encephalitis.
7. Venous thromboembolism: The patient's immobility and prolonged bed rest may increase the risk of venous thromboembolism, which can lead to pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's impaired bowel function may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as constipation, diarrhea, or gastrointestinal bleeding.
9. Infection: The patient's fever and altered mental status may be signs of an infection, which can spread and cause serious complications if left untreated.
10. Medication-related adverse effects: The patient's medication regimen may be causing adverse effects, such as allergic reactions, gastrointestinal upset, or respiratory depression.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with multiple comorbidities and ongoing medical issues.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37C (98.6F), heart rate of 112 beats per minute (bpm), and blood pressure of 155/82 mmHg. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 416 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

The patient's laboratory results indicate:

* WBC count: 8.7-9.7 K/uL
* Hct: 25.2-24.9%
* Plt: 232-198 K/uL
* Cr: 0.5-0.4 mg/dL
* TCO2: 28-30 mmHg
* Glucose: 119-105 mg/dL
* Other labs: Elevated levels of CK, CKMB, Troponin-T, ALT, AST, Alk Phos, T Bili, Amylase, and Lipase.

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Respiratory failure
* Impaired skin integrity
* Tachycardia
* Dyspnea
* Fever
* Altered mental status
* Impaired airway clearance
* Impaired balance
* Impaired muscle performance
* Impaired motor function
* Impaired posture
* Impaired ventilation
* Impaired cough

The patient is receiving ICU care, including mechanical ventilation, nutritional support with Nutren 2.0, and prophylactic measures for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Sepsis or septic shock due to the presence of fever and altered mental status
* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to the patient's respiratory failure
* Worsening of skin integrity and potential development of pressure ulcers
* Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism due to immobility
* Increased risk of stress ulcer and gastrointestinal bleeding due to the patient's tachycardia and altered mental status
* Development of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to the patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation
* Worsening of muscle performance and potential development of critical illness myopathy
* Increased risk of electrolyte imbalance and potential development of arrhythmias due to the patient's tachycardia and altered mental status.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 39 y/o M w/ wet beri-beri now transferred to ICU for
   persistent tachycardia/dyspnea and fevers
   .
   # Tachypnea / Respiratory distress: Patient with good RSBI and NIF over
   weekend however extubation was not attempted due to pt
s profound
   muscle weakness and concern that he may tire quickly and require
   re-intubation.  Trach placed [**4-11**].
   - Will attempt trach mask trial
   - Still awaiting BAL results (if pos for hemosiderin-laden Macros,
   pathology still pending).  ANCA and anti-GBM ordered and results
   pending.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Not fluid responsive. Stable. Likely related to fever,
   cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease. Also starting to become
   hypertensive.
   - stop captopril due to propensity to cause rashes
   - start metoprolol 12.5 mg TID and titrate upward as necessary
   .
   # Altered mental status:  Multiple etiologies
 chronic EtOH ingestion,
   delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction,
   dry beri beri and central pontine myelinolysis.
   - potential central pontine myelinolysis seen MRI brain [**2191-4-5**]. MRA is
   okay, ruling out ischemic etiology. Likely due to fast correction of
   hyponatremia on admission. Appreciate Neuro recs; unfortunately, it
   an irreversible process. Can cause visual problems.
   - Minimize sedating medications. Zyprexa may work better for delirium
   component of his mental status.
   - f/u neuro recs re: prognosis for cognitive recovery, any other
   necessary tests for work up, and the use of zyprexa for discomfort and
   agitation
   - No need for lactulose as patient is having large amounts of liquid
   diarrhea
   - Keppra stopped as potential cause for rash
 f/u with Neuro
   - continue nutritional support
   .
   # Fevers: Persistent fevers despite broad spectrum abx coverage (cipro,
   flagyl, vanc, zosyn -> meropenem) and was less febrile off all
   antibiotics.  Fever last night could represent drug fever.  ID has
   signed off, but will let them know that he is still spiking fevers.
   **Investigation for infection source so far:
   - Bronch
 BAL so far unrevealing. F/u on outstanding studies.
   - C. diff neg multiple times
   - fluid collection in stomach seen on imaging, however not amenable to
   drainage due to location.
   - small fluid collection extra-axially on MRI brain; not an abscess;
   repeat MRI [**4-12**]
   - pleural fluid labs
 so far NGTD
   - Continue oral hygiene; check for skin break down
   - Surveillance cultures
   - Consider repeat LP if all the above investigations negative for
   source of fever. However likely low yield, and pt is coagulopathic.
   - Consider paracentesis, although not much ascitic fluid seen by U/S.
   ([**Month (only) 51**] need IR for this)
   - RSV neg
   - F/u ID, neuro, and neurosurg recs
   - [**Month (only) 51**] be central (CNS) in etiology, however it
s a diagnosis of
   exclusion; considered unlikely since MRI brain did not show any
   bilateral hypothalamic lesions, however still in differential.
   .
   # Anemia: Pt has many reasons to be anemic; malnutrition, illness,
   guaiac pos stools. Likely having a very slow GI bleed.  Hct has been
   stable over the last several days.
   - Maintain Hct >21
   - Keep an active type and cross
   - PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Resolved.  Was stable in low 130s. Now improved to mid
   140s.
   - TSH WNL and appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim test
   - Trend Cr
   .
   # Beri-Beri: Dry/Wet features, echo hyperdynamic.
   - Continue B vitamins at increased doses, incl thiamine and pyridoxine
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR stable around 2. Likely due to alcoholic liver
   disease and malnutrition. Vit K given during this admission.
   - Will need Vit K and FFP before procedures to reverse coagulopathy (2U
   FFP [**4-11**] prior to trach/PEG)
   - follow Hct.
   .
   # Rash: developed raised, blanchable lesions trunk > extremities [**4-10**]
   - Derm input: watch for signs of mucosal involvement
   - Keppra and captopril stopped
 f/u with Neuro
   .
   # Etoh: Outside window for withdrawal.
   - SW consult.
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, on tube feeds.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, PPI; PT working with pt.
   .
   # Access: Left subclavian removed (placed [**4-4**]), A-line, peripheral,
   PICC to be placed
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Communication: Patient/ Parents.
   .
   # Disposition: Once Trach/PEG in place, ask case management to start
   screening for placement.
   - Family would like the patient to go to [**Hospital 189**] Rehab once medically
   ready.
   - Need to ask SW or case management to help file long-term disability
   papers.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Nutren 2.0 (Full) - [**2191-4-13**] 12:00 AM 55 mL/hour

Summary:

The patient is a 39-year-old male with a history of wet beri-beri, chronic EtOH ingestion, and altered mental status. He was transferred to the ICU for persistent tachycardia, dyspnea, and fevers. He has been experiencing a morbilliform rash, which is thought to be related to medications. His laboratory results show anemia, hyponatremia, and coagulopathy, which are likely related to his underlying medical conditions. He has been receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics and has had a bronchial alveolar lavage (BAL) and pleural fluid analysis, but no source of infection has been identified. He has also had a computed tomography (CT) scan of the head, which showed a small fluid collection extra-axially, but no abscess.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Central Pontine Myelinolysis: The patient's MRI brain showed a potential central pontine myelinolysis, which is an irreversible process that can cause visual problems.
2. Infection: Despite broad-spectrum antibiotics, the patient's fevers persist, and there is a concern that he may have an underlying infection that is not being effectively treated.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy is likely related to his underlying medical conditions, including alcoholic liver disease and malnutrition. This increases his risk of bleeding complications.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely related to his underlying medical conditions, including malnutrition and gastrointestinal bleeding. This increases his risk of fatigue and shortness of breath.
5. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia has resolved, but there is a concern that it may recur, particularly if he becomes dehydrated.
6. Beri-Beri: The patient's beri-beri is likely related to his underlying malnutrition and vitamin deficiencies. This increases his risk of further complications, including cardiac arrhythmias and neuropathy.
7. Skin Breakdown: The patient's morbilliform rash increases his risk of skin breakdown and infection.
8. Respiratory Failure: The patient's tachypnea and respiratory distress increase his risk of respiratory failure, particularly if he is not able to be extubated.
9. Cardiac Complications: The patient's tachycardia and hyperdynamic echo suggest that he may be at risk for cardiac complications, including arrhythmias and cardiac failure.

Summary:

The patient is a 39-year-old male with a history of chronic ethanol ingestion, wet beri-beri, and now transferred to the ICU for persistent tachycardia, dyspnea, and fever of unknown origin. He has a morbilliform rash and is on mechanical ventilation. The patient has a complex medical history, including cardiomyopathy, liver dysfunction, and central pontine myelinolysis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Infection: The patient has persistent fevers despite broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage, suggesting a possible infection source. Further investigation is needed to identify the source of the infection.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient's tachycardia is likely related to fever, cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease. The patient is also becoming hypertensive, which may require further management.
3. Neurological Complications: The patient has altered mental status, which may be due to chronic ethanol ingestion, delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction, dry beri-beri, and central pontine myelinolysis. Further neurology consultation is needed to determine the prognosis for cognitive recovery and potential treatments.
4. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient has guaiac-positive stools and is likely having a slow gastrointestinal bleed. Close monitoring of his hemoglobin levels and coagulation status is necessary.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient has an elevated INR, likely due to alcoholic liver disease and malnutrition. Close monitoring of his coagulation status and potential need for vitamin K and fresh frozen plasma (FFP) before procedures.
6. Skin Complications: The patient has a morbilliform rash, which may be related to medications such as Keppra and captopril. Close monitoring for signs of mucosal involvement and potential need for dermatology consultation.
7. Respiratory Complications: The patient is on mechanical ventilation and has a risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). Close monitoring of his respiratory status and potential need for bronchoscopy and antibiotics.
8. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient has had hyponatremia in the past, which has resolved. Close monitoring of his electrolyte levels is necessary to prevent future imbalances.
9. Nutritional Complications: The patient is receiving tube feeds and has a risk of malnutrition. Close monitoring of his nutritional status and potential need for adjustments to his diet.
10. Psychological Complications: The patient has a history of chronic ethanol ingestion and may be at risk for withdrawal. Close monitoring of his mental status and potential need for substance abuse consultation.

Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   - MRI read
   1. Unchanged small left subdural collection. Evaluation for contrast
   enhancement is again technically limited by patient motion artifact.
   2. Slightly increased prominence of the geographic focal T2-signal
